ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: The course was all virtual, and was a combination of lecture and breakout rooms/student participation.
The lectures were recorded and also some of it was seminar style.
none
N/A
A mixture of live virtual lecture and virtual seminar, depending on the day and topic.
Class was split between live virtual lectures and discussing practice/homework problems.
The lectures on grammar were also recorded for our convenience.

I studied using quizlet, and I studied with a classmate. I took notes during class, and I would read over them for review. I also relied heavily on the grammar summaries that professor Chantrain posted on canvas.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned the basics of hieroglyphic - how to transliterate and translate simple sentences. I learned about the nonverbal and verbal grammar system, and also some Egyptian history.
I learned the basics of the Ancient Egyptian Language.
I learned how to read Egyptian hieroglyphics, and developed an aptitude for the science of deduction.
Time management and knowledge of Ancient Egyptian hieroglyphs.
By the time you complete this course you will be able to read Egyptian sentences and understand Egyptian grammatical structures.

Teaching this class not only exposed me to another language, but made me think more critically about language and its structure. I learned to better analyze the English sentences I was creating and transliterating from Egyptian

I learned how to read Middle Egyptian hieroglyphic! I can actually go to museums and recognize the signs and some of the words used, sometimes even full sentences. Specifically, we primarily cover the grammar used in middle egyptian writing with some common vocabulary used in texts.

I learned how to read Middle Egyptian hieroglyphic with a focus on various grammatical structures. The class follows along with Allen's grammar book, covering nouns, adjectives, nonverbal sentences, and an introduction to the verbal system. Along with the language, we learned about Middle Egyptian culture, ideals, and thought.

I learned how to read Egyptian hieroglyphs, how to work together with my classmates, and some vital memorization skills. I also learned some very interesting insights into the culture in ancient Egypt.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Professor Chantrain is one of the kindest and most caring professors youll ever have. She is really passionate and knowledgeable about the subject and she will always support you to make the class as good of an experience as possible for you. If I had to change something, Id suggest more active learning. It was sometimes hard to keep up with all the grammar when it was being presented in class. Maybe it would be better to have us study the grammar in advance and practice in class.

The course was formatted quite well and it was easy to follow along and understand a lot of the concepts. It also wasn't expected of us to understand particularly hard concepts right away, so the stress level wasn't bad. Feedback was always very helpful and explanation would be given with it as well.

Strengths: the course material is quite doable. Prof Chantrain is VERY helpful, and you would have to deliberately refuse to learn if you want to find this course challenging. Exam-wise, I LOVED the course.  Weaknesses: none.

Strengths: Amazing professor, fun language, and manageable workload.
Weaknesses: The textbook exercises weren't very engaging; the exercises the professor made were more fun and understandable.
I think there could be more practical ways of learning the grammatical structures, rather than just practice sentences. But I also think that the lecture portion of the course was very well taught.

This course was great because of the professor. Learning hieroglyphs in and of itself is really cool, but Professor Chantrain really completed the class. She was always patient and available, helping students really understand the course material. The translations and transliterations we did were pretty straight forward.

Professor Chantrain is really great at explaining the content and provides very helpful summaries of the grammar. She really cares about the course and makes the content fun to learn. The course follows the textbook (Allan, 3rd edition) so between Professor Chantrain and the textbook, the material is presented very clearly. No weaknesses.

Professor Chantrain is an amazing professor! She is incredibly passionate and knowledgeable, touching on every little nuance and offering insight into ancient Egyptian culture. It is evident how much she cares about her students. She even compiled a presentation on artifacts from the Met since we were unable to go to a museum at the end of the semester. As a remote student, Middle Egyptian was the highlight of my early mornings. The relatively small class size lends itself well to working in groups on exercises and getting to know your peers. The material was presented at a good pace and we covered a lot more than I expected. The provided grammatical summaries are very helpful. Also, the assignment-oral exam testing format was very fair and minimized stress.
There sometimes feels like there is a lot to memorize, but that is the nature of Middle Egyptian. I thoroughly enjoyed the class and did not observe any significant weaknesses.

Despite having to memorize the signs, this class did not feel like it was only memorization. Professor Chantrain taught us the grammar required to understand the structure of sentences, and then allowed us to read sentences on our own using dictionaries and sign lists. By doing this, we were able to build a strong base understanding of the language without having to memorize too much at once. The only complaint I have about this class is that sometimes the lectures moved a bit fast and were long, so it was difficult for me to keep up with my notes, but this was fine because all of the notes that professor Chantrain presented in class were posted on canvas, so I could go back and study later.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The virtual classroom format worked well overall. I only wish we had been able to do the in-person aspects of the course, like seeing artifacts at the Met.
The lectures followed by exercises that we would go over together as a class helped keep me engaged and also worked well for the format.

We had pretty run-of-the-mill virtual seminars. We couldn't go to museums to look at actual stone slabs and read hieroglyphs but Prof Chantrain wonderfully makes up for that by showing us pictures of hieroglyphs on ancient chairs and whatnot.
It was the best you can do considering it was fully virtual.

Working together as a class or as teams in breakout rooms on reading exercises encouraged engagement. It also served as a break from lecture. I found the assignment-oral exam testing format to be ideal. I also really enjoyed the virtual tour of the Met.
Overall, the course was adapted well to this academic year. If anything, it would be helpful to work through more reading exercises during class.

Professor Chantrain did an excellent job at keeping us engaged by asking frequent questions and making us translate sentences in groups in class. Professor Chantrain also made it required to keep our cameras on during class, which I felt made the class more engaging and fun than some of my other classes.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes. Take this class if you want to fulfill your language requirement in an interesting way, just want to learn something cool and different, or want to have a very kind professor who supports your learning!
Yes, I would recommend this course because the professor was amazing and the information we learned was also super interesting. Also, when else will you be able to study hieroglyphics.
Absolutely. Worst case, you have an easy lang credit and a cool party trick. Best case, you become fascinated with the subject (like me)!
Absolutely! I loved this course; it's fun, engaging, and the professor is one of the best at Yale.

If you are interested in the language I would recommend it, but go into the course with the knowledge that if you get behind on one concept it will be hard to catch up as many of them build on top of one another.

I would definitely recommend this course, especially if you need a language requirement. The work and course is quite manageable. I never felt overwhelmed or anything by the amount of work that was given. It was really fun to learn in this class.

Absolutely! Most classes were split roughly into three parts: (1) go over and review the homework, (2) lecture on new content, and (3) work on some practice problems from the new content. Professor Chantrain is really good at explaining the material and care a lot. I'm so happy I get to take this class when she is the professor because it is so much fun. The assignments aren't too bad once you start remembering all the grammar rules and common signs. Most of the time, the homework can be completed quickly but the first homework on adjectives and the first homework on verbs took me a while because the was new and a bit complex. Professor Chantrain does a great job explaining it, though.

YES!! This was arguably my most favorite class this semester. The warm atmosphere and community are fantastic. Professor Chantrain is super kind and helpful; she is committed to helping you learn. Middle Egyptian itself is a beautiful language. As you dive into the language, you learn more about ancient Egyptian culture and realize what we share as part of the human condition. Also, it is pretty neat just to be able to read hieroglyphic. Testing is very fair and homework is minimal. I would definitely take this class!

I would highly recommend this class. It's easygoing, but engaging at the same time. Most importantly, it's fun! Translating hieroglyphs is something that I thought I would never do and it took me by surprise how enjoying it is.
